commit_message:
[PoC][Don't review] Testing delay

This is just some code to facilitate manual testing of the HA A/A
functionality.

It just introduces a 30 seconds delay to create volume, create snapshot,
delete volume, and delete snapshot.

For create volume it will introduce the delay before the creation, but
in the case of downloading from an image it will introduce the delay
right after updating the status of the volume to "downloading".

Change-Id: If3c817fcbd176ef5666709730bc705b5ec8135f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/69/353069/26 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This is meant to allow HA A/A manual testing # If we are create the volume from an image, the delay will be after # we change the status to downloading. if not request_spec.get('image_id'): vol_utils.introduce_delay(30, 'volume create', volume.id) # This is meant to allow HA A/A manual testing vol_utils.introduce_delay(30, 'volume delete', volume.id) # This is meant to allow HA A/A manual testing vol_utils.introduce_delay(30, 'snapshot create', snapshot.id) # This is meant to allow HA A/A manual testing vol_utils.introduce_delay(30, 'snapshot delete', snapshot.id)

RBD driver.

commit_message:
Delete volume when rescheduling

If a reschedulable failure happens in the driver after the volume was
created on the backend, it will get orphaned and only way to remove it
will be through backend internals. This commit adds an additional
delete_volume call to the driver after the volume got rescheduled to
make sure no volumes will get orphaned.

Change-Id: Idd86a4842bdc6ecf0cabbeff0a9c9704e030302a
Closes-Bug: 1561579
(cherry picked from commit 7f09229d6cdc7a7f002123038cda82929926552c)
(cherry picked from commit b3b2e136c72356865596126914b103935337f9bc)

commit_message:
backup of active 3par ISCSI bootable volume fails

1.Backup of ISCSI volume with chap enabled on it, fails
because it choose online copy code path where copy
volume is background process on 3par and we do not
wait for process to complete and setting of any attribute
on cloned volume failed during online copy of data.
This patch ensures it choses non online copy code path
for above scenario.

2.Backup of attached volume fails with snapCPG error
Sometime, during online clone operation, we set snapCPG and
userCPG on cloned volume but when we get cpg of
cloned volume we get an error as these attributes
do not set for cloned volume on 3par.
This patch ensure if cpg is not available for volume
from 3par it will take default value from 'host' attribute
from volume param.

Closes-Bug: #1644238
Closes-Bug: #1646396

Change-Id: Icb5c8ebd518ea01793d97d3ecf20610c10fe2535

subject: CoprHD: Handle deletion of volumes in error state
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-06 14:27:07.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/coprhd/common.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/coprhd/scaleio.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/00458cd41e2e44f43fab8ac29d1cc39894f36acc', 'message': "CoprHD: Handle deletion of volumes in error state

Currently the CoprHD driver uses Openstack tags to
search for the volume and if the tags are found the
volume gets deleted. But the tags are set only after
the full operation has been completed.

In certain cases when an operation involving multi-steps,
e.g create_cloned_volume() (involves:creating full volume copy,
detaching cloned volume from source volume and expanding the
cloned volume if asked to do so) fails, a resource is created
without tags in ViPR and it is shown in an error state in
Openstack. We've added logic to remove such resources from
ViPR without the volume entering into a permanent 'Error Deleting' state.

Change-Id: Ia378676dd312a5b483476c924306abe4183e9d58
Closes-Bug: #1653630
"}]
commit_message:
CoprHD: Handle deletion of volumes in error state

Currently the CoprHD driver uses Openstack tags to
search for the volume and if the tags are found the
volume gets deleted. But the tags are set only after
the full operation has been completed.

In certain cases when an operation involving multi-steps,
e.g create_cloned_volume() (involves:creating full volume copy,
detaching cloned volume from source volume and expanding the
cloned volume if asked to do so) fails, a resource is created
without tags in ViPR and it is shown in an error state in
Openstack. We've added logic to remove such resources from
ViPR without the volume entering into a permanent 'Error Deleting' state.

Change-Id: Ia378676dd312a5b483476c924306abe4183e9d58
Closes-Bug: #1653630

commit_message:
Storwize: Add volume qos parameter Bandwidth_limit

From Storwize Release 7.7 , there is a new qos parameter Bandwidth_limit
for  volume. This patch is to add the Bandwidth_limit to qos parameter
support list.

DocImpact
Adds qos config 'Bandwidth_limit'

Change-Id: I3fd5d219563b66378d9cddf15a00022f396a4fc5
Closes-Bug: 1642475

Implement nfs manage/unmanage of a volume

This bp is aim to implement nfs manage/unmanage of a volume.

Implements: blueprint nfs-manage-unmanage-volume

added_lines: import mathfrom oslo_utils import excutilsfrom cinder.volume import utils as volutils def manage_existing(self, volume, existing_ref): """Manages an existing volume. Renames the volume to match the expected name for the volume. Error checking done by manage_existing_get_size is not repeated. """ vol_name = existing_ref['source-name'] if volutils.check_already_managed_volume(vol_name): raise exception.ManageExistingAlreadyManaged(volume_ref=vol_name) # Attempt to rename the volume to match the OpenStack internal name. try: self._rename_volume(vol_name, volume['name']) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: exception_message = (_("Failed to rename volume %(name)s, " "error message was: %(err_msg)s") % {'name': vol_name, 'err_msg': exc.stderr}) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException( data=exception_message) def manage_existing_get_size(self, existing_object, existing_ref): """Return size of an existing volume for manage existing volume. existing_ref is a dictionary of the form: {'source-name': <name of volume>} """ # Check that the reference is valid if 'source-name' not in existing_ref: reason = _('Reference must contain source-name element.') raise exception.ManageExistingInvalidReference( existing_ref=existing_ref, reason=reason) vol_name = existing_ref['source-name'] vol = self._get_volume(vol_name) # Raise an exception if we didn't find a suitable volume. if not vol: kwargs = {'existing_ref': vol_name, 'reason': 'Specified logical volume does not exist.'} raise exception.ManageExistingInvalidReference(**kwargs) try: vol_size = int(math.ceil(float(vol['size']) / units.Gi)) except ValueError: exception_message = (_("Failed to manage existing " "%(name)s, because reported size %(size)s " "was not a floating-point number.") % {'name': vol_name, 'size': vol['size']}) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException( data=exception_message) return vol_size def _get_volumes(self): """Get all nfs volumes. :returns: List of Dictionaries with volume info """ run_as_root = self._execute_as_root vol_list = [] self._ensure_shares_mounted() if not self._mounted_shares: raise exception.NfsNoSharesMounted() mount_point = self._get_mount_point_for_share(self._mounted_shares[0]) du, _ = self._execute('du', r"-ab", mount_point, run_as_root=run_as_root) if du is not None: volumes = du.split() iterator = six.moves.zip(*[iter(volumes)] * 2) for size, name in iterator: vol_list.append({"name": name.replace(mount_point + '/', ''), "size": size}) return vol_list def _get_volume(self, name): """Get reference object of volume specified by name. :returns: dict representation of Logical Volume if exists """ ref_list = self._get_volumes() for ref in ref_list: if ref["name"] == name: return ref return None def _rename_volume(self, vol_name, new_name): """Change the name of an existing volume.""" self._ensure_shares_mounted() if not self._mounted_shares: raise exception.NfsNoSharesMounted() mount_point = self._get_mount_point_for_share(self._mounted_shares[0]) src_volume = mount_point + r"/" + vol_name dest_volume = src_volume.replace(vol_name, new_name) try: self._execute('mv', src_volume, dest_volume, run_as_root=True) except putils.ProcessExecutionError: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.exception(_LE('Error renaming volume')) def unmanage(self, volume): pass

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-28 17:28:45.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/exception.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_lvm_driver.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/1db6e14464160f3691dccf34a7749aeecd2f2a30', 'message': 'Cinder - Prevent LVM backend overallocation when creating snapshots

If cinder-volume LVM backend is configured as thin-provisioning, when
requesting a snapshot there is currently no check for free space. This
allows us to create a large volume, dirty it, make a snapshot, rewrite

commit_message:
Cinder - Prevent LVM backend overallocation when creating snapshots

If cinder-volume LVM backend is configured as thin-provisioning, when
requesting a snapshot there is currently no check for free space. This
allows us to create a large volume, dirty it, make a snapshot, rewrite
the original volume, and run out of space in the thin pool.

Change-Id: I6d41ab37a6e473290916237551fe614790c3fe2b
Closes-Bug: #1605033
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/91/348491/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The following check is targeted at thin pools to ensure that we # don't over allocate when creating a snapshot. if (self.configuration.lvm_type == 'thin' and self.configuration.max_over_subscription_ratio >= 1): source_lvref = self.vg.get_volume(snapshot['volume_name']) volume_size_gb = float(source_lvref['size']) provisioned_ratio = ((self.vg.vg_provisioned_capacity + volume_size_gb) / self.vg.vg_size) if (provisioned_ratio > self.configuration.max_over_subscription_ratio): ratio = self.configuration.max_over_subscription_ratio raise exception.ThinPoolCapacityError( provisioned_ratio=provisioned_ratio, oversub_ratio=ratio, host=self.hostname)

commit_message:
Initialize LVM volumes via ploop

Virtuozzo containers can work only with formatted disks.
Block device must have GPT table and one partition.
If we have 'ploop_init' metadata key that we initialize new LVM volume
via 'ploop init'. As result this tool creates one partition and
formats it as ext4 filesystem. But after this operation there is a
link to a new partition in /dev/mapper/. We should delete
this partition link via 'dmsetup'. If we don't do it, than we can't
delete LVM volume because it has addition link to this partition.

Change-Id: I1ef3d34342546d4da9ea434f548ac1857bb3cdbf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/89/357989/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_partitions(self, volume_path): out, _ = self._execute('lsblk', '-l', '-o', 'NAME', '-n', volume_path, run_as_root=True) lines = out.split('\n') if len(lines) < 2: return None lines.pop(0) return lines def _ploop_init_vol(self, volume_path): try: self._execute('ploop', 'initdev', volume_path, run_as_root=True) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: raise exception.VolumePloopInitException(vol_path=volume_path, reason=exc.stderr) finally: partitions = self._get_partitions(volume_path) if partitions is not None: dev_base = os.path.dirname(volume_path) partitions.reverse() for i in partitions: if i == '': continue partition_path = os.path.join(dev_base, i) self._execute('dmsetup', 'remove', partition_path, run_as_root=True) if ('ploop_init' in volume.metadata and volume.metadata['ploop_init'] == 'yes'): self._ploop_init_vol(self.local_path(volume))

commit_message:
Return HTTPBadRequest instead of HTTPNotFound

If non-existing volume-id, snapshot-id etc are passed to following
api's then it returns 404 HTTPNotFound error:

1. manage snapshot
2. create snapshot
3. create volume
4. create group snapshot
5. create consistencygroups

According to the api guidelines [1] it should return 400 HTTPBadRequest.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/api-wg/blob/master/guidelines/http.rst#failure-code-clarifications

APIImpact: 400 error instead of 404 will be returned when user will pass
non-existing parameters in body to the above listed API's.

Change-Id: I0546b869744915672318691d527f10f56e99a32c
Closes-Bug: #1640173

commit_message:
Replace six iteration methods with standard ones

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using six.iteritems/keys
achieve iterators. We can use dict.items/keys instead, as it will
return iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys will more readable.
2.In py2, the performance about list should be negligible, see the
link [2].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/ 2015-June/066391.html

TrivialFix.

Change-Id: Id604ecbcaaebb2464ef831fc7fa2dc1b45a0a03d

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-10 08:53:24.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/unit/test_sheepdog.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/sheepdog.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/0a310b30920574d82953406b01e7598d19b79d68', 'message': "Sheepdog: fix clone failure

In the case that Cinder and Glance use same Sheepdog cluster as
their backend, a image is clonable without data copying.

When image A will be cloned to volume B, the Sheepdog's internal
mecanism is following:

1. Make a snapshot C of image A using dog command.
2. Clone snapshot C to Volume B using qemu-img command.

The name of snapshot C is [image A's UUID]-temp-snapshot

But qemu-img cannot accept such a name.

"}]
commit_message:
Sheepdog: fix clone failure

In the case that Cinder and Glance use same Sheepdog cluster as
their backend, a image is clonable without data copying.

When image A will be cloned to volume B, the Sheepdog's internal
mecanism is following:

1. Make a snapshot C of image A using dog command.
2. Clone snapshot C to Volume B using qemu-img command.

The name of snapshot C is [image A's UUID]-temp-snapshot
So it sometimes starts with a number.
But qemu-img cannot accept such a name.

Closes-Bug: #1625530
(cherry picked from commit cc123d5ed6c7c748754b18e801b5c175c5b1c5f4)
(cherry picked from commit 44369a911374dce96fe11a6266776af5c25b5c15)

Conflicts:
	cinder/volume/drivers/sheepdog.py

Change-Id: I20bf1dca058fef31b9f244a4fcc3800b62eadf15

added_lines: snapshot_name = 'tmp-snap-%s' % src_vref['name']

commit_message:
[RBD]Add a configuation to enable the volume to be multiattached

The RBD capacity about multiattach should be configurable
rather than freezon 'False' in the code.

Change-Id: Ie810d8f594607e3a724f9356d985cb555f8c2793
Closes-bug: #1655526

subject: inder Client Automatic Microversion Selection
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-24 19:14:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient/commit/0a8eec6e77266492df80b5a58ae14458c42b9dcb', 'message': 'inder Client Automatic Microversion Selection

============
Introduction
============

With the Nova, Manilla and Cinder projects implementing support for
microversions, the Openstack Client itself is not microversion aware and
present a "ease of use" issue when trying to use a feature that may or
may not be present in the currently running version of the cinder
service. Currently, this is not a issue for the Manilla project, because
its developers have implemented a auto-negotiation feature to
automatically call the highest api version of the service if available.
This is not the case for the Cinder client. In order for one
to make an api call to the Cinder service, at least the minimum
microversion at which the api call was implemented has be known at the
time of the api call. As of Cinder v3, the microversion must be provided
in the HTTP request header, otherwise it falls back to v3.0 which is
identical to v2.

===========
The Problem
===========

Currently, the caller of any API calls to the Cinder v3 API must know
the specific version of the API that they want to use. By default,
Cinder assumes that you meant to use 3.0 if no version is specified.
This behavior is likely to maintain backwards compatibility with the v2
API.

========
Solution
========

The solution to this problem would be to query the version api, which is
present at each endpoint, for the current version of Cinder v3 API.
Then the version that is returned can be passed to the Cinder client if
it is compatible. This way the most currently available version of the
Cinder v3 API is always used.

==============
Needed Changes
==============

The current behavior is to fallback to v3.0 if no version is specifed.
This behavior will need to be changed to attempt to choose the highest
compatible version. If no version is compatiable, then fallback to
v3.0. A variable (MIN_SUPPORTED_VERSION ???) must be added to indicate
the minimum version that the current (MAX_VERSION) version of the client
can interact with. This minimum version variable must be elevated when a
backwards compatibility breaking change is introduced at a new
microversion.

                        PCC = Python Cinder Client
==========
Scenario A
==========

API Versions  |3.0 --- 3.1|
PCC Versions  |3.0 -------- 3.2|

The client will use v3.1, but some API calls will not be available
(should 404). This case should really not be allowed, but is possible.

==========
Scenario B
==========

API Versions           |3.3 --- 3.5|
PCC Versions  |3.1 -------- 3.4|

The client will use v3.4 and all of the commands that were present a the
time of v3.4 will be available.

==========
Scenario C
==========

API Versions                    |3.6 --- 3.8|
PCC Versions  |3.1 --- 3.3|

The client is not compatible, but the client will fallback to v3.0 to
maintain minimal functionality.

==========
Conclusion
==========

The solution detailed above will greatly simplify the use of the Cinder
python client with the v3 API by allowing not specifying a specific API
version and making use of the latest compatible version of the v3 api.
This will also allow the OpenStack client to make use of new features
of the Cinder API more easily as they become available in the  future
if the user is running the latest version of the Cinder service.

==========
References
==========

REST API Version History
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/cinder/devref/api_microversion_history.html

API Microversions for Operators- What? Why? and How?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=7KdNiuf2f9s

API Microversions
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/cinder/devref/api_microversion_dev.html

Novas Kilo spec for microversions
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova-specs/tree/specs/kilo/implemented/api-microversions.rst

Advanced Microversion Support - Client : Blueprints : python-manilaclient
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-manilaclient/+spec/manila-client-advanced-microversion-support

Various Discussions via IRC

Change-Id: I2e315b19adae4aae39c0a6005a0dda41e50b9682

============

time of the api call. As of Cinder v3, the microversion must be provided
in the HTTP request header, otherwise it falls back to v3.0 which is
identical to v2.

===========

===========

Currently, the caller of any API calls to the Cinder v3 API must know

Then the version that is returned can be passed to the Cinder client if

API Versions  |3.0 --- 3.1|
PCC Versions  |3.0 -------- 3.2|

API Versions           |3.3 --- 3.5|
PCC Versions  |3.1 -------- 3.4|

Scenario C
==========

API Versions                    |3.6 --- 3.8|
PCC Versions  |3.1 --- 3.3|

The client is not compatible, but the client will fallback to v3.0 to
maintain minimal functionality.

==========
Conclusion
==========

The solution detailed above will greatly simplify the use of the Cinder
python client with the v3 API by allowing not specifying a specific API
version and making use of the latest compatible version of the v3 api.
This will also allow the OpenStack client to make use of new features
of the Cinder API more easily as they become available in the  future
if the user is running the latest version of the Cinder service.

==========
References
==========

REST API Version History
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/cinder/devref/api_microversion_history.html

API Microversions for Operators- What? Why? and How?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=7KdNiuf2f9s

API Microversions
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/cinder/devref/api_microversion_dev.html

Novas Kilo spec for microversions
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova-specs/tree/specs/kilo/implemented/api-microversions.rst

Advanced Microversion Support - Client : Blueprints : python-manilaclient
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-manilaclient/+spec/manila-client-advanced-microversion-support

Various Discussions via IRC

Change-Id: I2e315b19adae4aae39c0a6005a0dda41e50b9682

commit_message:
Adds support for min/max volume size on vol_type

Allows support for setting a minimum and/or maximum vol size that
can be created in extra_specs for each volume_type. This allows
setting size restrictions on different "tiers" of storage.
If configured, the size restrictions will be checked at the API level
as part of volume creation or retype.

Implements: blueprint min-max-vol-size-by-vol-type

DocImpact

Co-Authored-By: Xinli Guan <xinli@us.ibm.com>

Change-Id: Ie7a20b28b5f6b2c5d956b03f6d39f30ec10c2ed9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/48/278648/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MIN_SIZE_KEY = "provisioning:min_vol_size" MAX_SIZE_KEY = "provisioning:max_vol_size" def _validate_volume_size_within_limits(self, req_size, vol_type): """Validates that requested volume size is within vol type size limits. :param req_size: integer of the requested size :param vol_type: volume_type to check limits of :raises InvalidInput if req_size is outside of the size restrictions """ extra_specs = vol_type.get('extra_specs', {}) min_size = extra_specs.get(MIN_SIZE_KEY) if min_size and req_size < int(min_size): msg = _("Specified volume size of '%(req_size)d' is less " "than the minimum required size of '%(min_size)s' " "for volume type '%(vol_type)s'.") % { 'req_size': req_size, 'min_size': min_size, 'vol_type': vol_type['name'] } raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg) max_size = extra_specs.get(MAX_SIZE_KEY) if max_size and req_size > int(max_size): msg = _("Specified volume size of '%(req_size)d' is " "greater than the maximum allowable size of " "'%(max_size)s' for volume type '%(vol_type)s'." ) % { 'req_size': req_size, 'max_size': max_size, 'vol_type': vol_type['name']} raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg) if size: # Compare the size of the volume to any size restrictions that may # exist on the volume type vol_type = volume_type if not vol_type: vol_type = volume_types.get_default_volume_type() # if no volume type specified (and no default), then don't do # any validaiton if vol_type: size_int = int(size) self._validate_volume_size_within_limits(size_int, vol_type) self._validate_volume_size_within_limits(int(volume['size']), vol_type)

commit_message:
AIO: Provide facility to exclude apt distributions

When using a mirror which compiles all apt sources into
a single repo with the intent of relying on that repo for
all package updates the /etc/apt/sources.list file must
contain only the base ubuntu repo.

This patch adds the ability to implement an AIO with
this kind of apt sources configuration, while keeping
the current configuration that's used for gating.

Change-Id: Ia9785a43c9027df86f3bc94f825aba3c43a96e4c
(cherry picked from commit ae6a0055d475fdfbabf59790d5810465b8d85d0a)

commit_message:
Event-driven heal_and_optimize for SR-IOV

Invoke a heal_and_optimize if SR-IOV physical port config change events
are received.

Closes-Bug: #1658978
Change-Id: I1eb4bb1d802eee0a455acc9531f7547b48b331b0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-powervm refs/changes/78/436078/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def is_hao_event(self, event): """Determines if an Event warrants a heal_and_optimize. :param event: A pypowervm.wrappers.event.Event wrapper to inspect. :return: True if heal_and_optimize should be invoked as a result of this event; False otherwise. """ return event.detail == 'SRIOVPhysicalPort.ConfigChange'

commit_message:
Switch to use test_utils.call_until_true

test.call_until_true has been deprecated since Newton on Tempest side,
and now Tempest provides test_utils.call_until_true as the stable
library method. So this patch switches to use the stable method before
removing old test.call_until_true on Tempest side.

Change-Id: I75d289f27d4e5e02243150dfaca08824d9e5aafa
Needed-by: Ide11a7434a4714e5d2211af1803333535f557370

subject: Set OVS inactivity_probe to vsctl_timeout when adding manager
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-03 17:56:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/1bd75ac4a788cfd5dee8963a47499db08cabf71a', 'message': "Set OVS inactivity_probe to vsctl_timeout when adding manager

If the vsctl_timeout > OVS's inactivity probe interval and a
transaction execution time exceeds the probe interval, OVS will
disconnect and the transaction will return TRY_AGAIN and most
likely repeat failing until the vsctl_timeout is reached. This
change adds ensures that the failsafe creation of the manager sets
the inactivity probe to the vsctl_timeout value.

Currently the patch doesn't override the probe_interval on an
existing Manager since it is possible that connection is used by
outside applications and it theoretically should be handled at
deployment.

Change-Id: I76fa0a0cf04a166edf062086fceb2fd90960ad6b
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-03-03 18:36:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/528791b7c369ffb1872d8ab60be5f05e383f84a5', 'message': "Set OVS inactivity_probe to vsctl_timeout when adding manager

If the vsctl_timeout > OVS's inactivity probe interval and a
transaction execution time exceeds the probe interval, OVS will
disconnect and the transaction will return TRY_AGAIN and most
likely repeat failing until the vsctl_timeout is reached. This
change adds ensures that the failsafe creation of the manager sets
the inactivity probe to the vsctl_timeout value.

Currently the patch doesn't override the probe_interval on an
existing Manager since it is possible that connection is used by
outside applications and it theoretically should be handled at

commit_message:
Set OVS inactivity_probe to vsctl_timeout when adding manager

If the vsctl_timeout > OVS's inactivity probe interval and a
transaction execution time exceeds the probe interval, OVS will
disconnect and the transaction will return TRY_AGAIN and most
likely repeat failing until the vsctl_timeout is reached. This
change ensures that the "failsafe" creation of the manager also
sets the inactivity probe to the vsctl_timeout value.

Currently the patch doesn't override the probe_interval on an
existing Manager since it is possible that connection is used by
outside applications and it theoretically should be handled at
deployment.

Related-Bug: #1627106
Change-Id: I76fa0a0cf04a166edf062086fceb2fd90960ad6b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/58/441258/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Agent initialization was fixed

When Murano Agent is disabled Agent was not
initialized properly which caused deployment errors
even if no agent calls made

Change-Id: I047b512cafe71650d6a5c7edc7863f0231292a22
Closes-Bug: #1670511

commit_message:
Renames wait_for_volume_status in tempest tests for consistency.

A recent change in Tempest [0] is breaking 2 murano tempest tests;
wait_for_volume_status was changed to wait_for_volume_resource_status,
causing an AttributeError to be thrown [1].

Additionally, a recent change in Cinder [2] removed multiattach
for all drivers, causing one of the murano tempest scenario tests
involving deploying an environment using a multiattach-enabled volume
to fail.

This patch renames the function wait_for_volume_status to be compatible
with the recent Tempest change. It also uses staticmethod delete
functions provided by the Tempest API for delete_volume and
delete_snapshot. It also removes the multiattach property in the
relevant tempest test.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/394588/29/tempest/common/waiters.py
[1] http://logs.openstack.org/01/435101/2/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-murano-api-ubuntu-xenial/911be71/console.html
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/428365/

Related-Bug: #1668848
Co-Authored-By: ricolin <rico.lin@easystack.cn>
Change-Id: I15ae3f9c931ba606883a22a5af719f79685093a7
(cherry picked from commit 10752e6bbad27c5f04e658114b94cad40ccc7423)

deleted_lines: cls.delete_volume(cls.volume) "openstackId": self.volume self.check_volume_attached('testMurano', self.volume) "openstackId": self.volume self.assertEqual(volume_data['source_volid'], self.volume) snapshot = self.create_snapshot(self.volume) self.addCleanup(self.delete_snapshot, snapshot) "openstackId": snapshot self.assertEqual(volume_data['snapshot_id'], snapshot) cls.delete_volume(cls.volume) def test_deploy_app_with_volume_creation_readonly_multiattach(self): """Test app deploy with volume creation with multiattach and readonly attach Cinder volume with size 1 GiB, multiattach and readonly multiattach, readonly attributes "readOnly": True, "multiattach": True self.assertTrue(volume_data['multiattach']) backup = self.create_backup(self.volume) self.addCleanup(self.delete_backup, backup) "name": "restore_backup_" + backup, "openstackId": backup self.assertIn(backup, volume_data['name'])

commit_message:
Remove barbican-tempest-plugin install from devstack plugin

The barbican-tempest-plugin should be installed through the gate
configuration rather than when barbican devstack plugin is enabled.

Removes some of the changes added in I376d58cad9a33dc90afdd0bf01e1e73bdd5a8b28

Co-Authored-By: Brianna Poulos <Brianna.Poulos@jhuapl.edu>

commit_message:
Switch to use exec_command instead of mount/umount

Both mount and umount are internal methods on Tempest side and these
methods need to be cleaned up for avoiding deep stacktrace.
The commit I914b09e0b242fbfba92cf35341941e5426c623eb will remove these
methods, so this patch is helpful for avoiding the gate issue.

Change-Id: I1bc849115c2b7eb7753c0bc3e0fe75424cb680d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/21/442721/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ssh_client.exec_command('sudo mount /dev/%s %s' % (dev_name, mount_path)) ssh_client.exec_command('sudo umount %s' % mount_path) ssh_client.exec_command('sudo mount /dev/%s %s' % (dev_name, mount_path)) ssh_client.exec_command('sudo umount %s' % mount_path)

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/55/443755/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: By default, Quality of Service (QoS) policies and rules will be managed by the cloud administrator, which results in tenants being unable to create specific QoS rules, or attaching specific ports to policies. In some use cases, like telco, the administrator may trust the tenants and therefore let them create and attach their own policies to ports. Those use cases would be supported by modification of ``policy.json`` and `specific documentation <https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/liberty/qos-api-extension.html>`__. will be released with the extension. The Networking service (neutron) has supported Bandwidth limiting QoS support since Liberty. QoS rule was named the ``QosBandwidthLimitRule`` and it accepts two non-negative integers: ``max-kbps`` is the bandwidth measured in kilobits per second and ``max-burst-kbps`` is the burst buffer measured in kilobits. The ``QoSBandwidthLimitRule`` has been implemented in the Neutron Open vSwitch, linux bridge and single root input/output virtualization (SR-IOV) drivers. The most recent addition to the QoS rules is the ``QosDscpMarkingRule``,Service Code Point (DSCP) value in the type of service header on IPv4 (RFC 2474) and traffic class header on IPv6 on all traffic leaving aTap-as-a-Service (TaaS) is an extension to the OpenStack networking service (neutron). It provides remote port mirroring capability for tenant virtual networks. Port mirroring involves sending a copy of packets entering or leaving one port to another port, which is usuallyapplications.

In some use cases, like telcos, the administrator may trust the tenants, and therefore let them create and attach their own policies to ports. Those use cases would be supported by modification of policy.json and specific documentation will be released with the extension. Neutron has supported Bandwidth limiting QoS support since Liberty. QoS rule was named the QosBandwidthLimitRule and it accepts two non-negative integers: max-kbps is the bandwidth measured in kilobits per second and max-burst-kbps is the burst buffer measured in kilobits. The QoSBandwidthLimitRule has been implemented in the Neutron Open vSwitch, linuxbridge and single root input/output virtualization (SR-IOV) drivers. The most recent addition to the QoS rules is the QosDscpMarkingRule,Service Code Point (DSCP) value in the type of service header on ipv4 (RFC 2474) and traffic class header on ipv6 on all traffic leaving aTap-as-a-Service (TaaS) is an extension to the OpenStack network service (Neutron). It provides remote port mirroring capability for tenant virtual networks. Port mirroring involves sending a copy of packets entering and/or leaving one port to another port, which is usuallyapplications (e.g. IDS).

commit_message:
Use Sphinx 1.5 warning-is-error

With pbr 2.0 and Sphinx 1.5, the setting for treat sphinx warnings as
errors is setting warning-is-error in build_sphinx section. Migrate
the setting from the old warnerrors one.

Fix problems found:
* Duplicate labels (rename wrong faq entries, rename unused drivers
  entries)
* Add api/autoindex.rst as hidden to the index so that we do not get a
  warning. The modindex includes the same content, so no need to show
  this.
* Add releasenotes/index.rst, webapi/v1.rst, user-guide, and install-guide.rst
  to hidden index since they're not listed in index on purpose, so sphinx
  will not warn that they do not appear in a toc
* Add deploy/radosgw to index
* ignore app.add_directiv warning
* Fix reference to user-guide to use proper markup so that Sphinx knows
  the user-guide is referenced.

Change-Id: I00d249229d4d31ba36d4393d60847fdb1513a744

commit_message:
Switch to use exec_command instead of mount/umount

Both mount and umount are internal methods on Tempest side and these
methods need to be cleaned up for avoiding deep stacktrace.
The commit I914b09e0b242fbfba92cf35341941e5426c623eb will remove these
methods, so this patch is helpful for avoiding the gate issue.

Change-Id: Ia540d0b4a6da0e9bf0180dfcafe34c60499a4356

deleted_lines: ssh_client.mount(dev_name, mount_path) ssh_client.umount(mount_path) ssh_client.mount(dev_name, mount_path) ssh_client.umount(mount_path)

commit_message:
charm-helpers sync to pickup changes to CephContext

CephContext now is capable of dealing with a space separated list of IPs
in the ceph-public-address field of the relation with ceph. This allows
ceph-proxy to pass a list of monitor hosts instead of a single one.

Change-Id: I14912e28414498de4960e11b724d11c2bfb039c5
Partial-Bug: 1642430

commit_message:
Remove redstack references

the trove-integration project has been rehomed in the trove repo
with a new name: trovestack

This changes the names to the new one.

Change-Id: I3f05f75456551bc80f013b1f5ab22d6f2f7f4e42

commit_message:
Refactor Volumes from tabbed panel to stand-alone

This edit unfortunately contains more changes than the others
because it effectively merges a bunch of files under
admin/volumes/*.py

Change-Id: I52f3444a92fc83982a95760673419b4b4d746ad3
Implements: blueprint reorganise-volumes

commit_message:
Helm 2.2 and localpath

This PS updates Helm to 2.2.2 and switches all the helm packages to
use the new local path feature.

Implements: blueprint helm-local-path
Change-Id: I0c128c2e1d74b17f147503fc9157ff257d27e02a
